turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: The school was acting, Your Honor, under a very broad state statute which gives --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, is there any question about that, do we have to look into that?

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
The question --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You have to accept that it's being a law of Iowa?

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: Yes, I think that's true.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They were engaged in doing what the law gives them the right to do.

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: It gives them the power to do, yes Your Honor.
But I, the point I'm -- I'd like to impress upon the Court this time is on pages 44 and 50 and 51 of the record.

It's very amply stated by respondents that other kinds of political insignia including the iron cross were worn in the schools that they were not covered by this policy, that there was no policy covering them, that it was simply this one policy against the wearing of the armbands in this context.
Now, counsel indicates that there was some sort of explosive situation which made this as a special circumstance.
I can't of course recite to the record to prove a negative.
I can just simply say that I don't believe that the record supports that kind of a situation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if that's a valid rule it was an explosive situation and a disruption was it not?
If it's a valid rule.

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor it is but our point is that the rule is not valid.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: Because it's based --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It gets back to that issue?

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: -- and because it's based solely upon a Fourteenth Amendment alone type stand of reasonableness.
And this Court --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I must say I agree to some of the implication of my Brother Fortas about that reasonableness rule.
I don't think that case has been cited approvingly in many, many years.
And I think the Court was very careful to say this morning that it wasn't citing that case to allow.

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: Well, for instance in the case of -- in the Barnette case which we've cited in the brief which was the case of the compulsory flag salute.

This Court specifically said that mere Fourteenth Amendment test of reasonableness are not sufficient in the schools when the students are engaged in something or where the conduct involves something that's privilege under the First Amendment.
That's the suggestion we have here.
Now, the reasons for the school board establishing the regulation are set out in page 70 of the record at quite some length by a document promulgated by the school board itself.
Counsel referred to them, those reasons which were by the way passed or at least reduced the paper after the suspensions in a week after the suspensions.
Simply to my reading of the decisions of this Court do not provide sufficient grounds for the subordination of freedom of expression.
Now, --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, is it your view that your State of Iowa is without power if it sees fit, to ban political discussions in the school hours where children are being taught?

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: It would not -- it has that power.
I believe it has the power but it's not necessary in this case because that's not what they've done, Your Honor.
They've banned only the discussion in one specific instance and that's all there is.
Now, I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You have almost an equal protection argument now.

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: Excuse me, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You have something close to an equal protection argument?

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: In addition to the other argument that I want to make and that is -- and I believe the stronger argument is not the equal protection argument, not the censorship by discrimination argument Mr. Justice Black has called it.

But as a matter of fact the stronger argument is that the interest of the state sought to protect whatever that may have been it's set out on page 70 of the record simply was not sufficient where as it might have been sufficient to justify the suppression of something it was privileged under the First Amendment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, now you have the real interest that the state is trying to protect is the right of the state authorities and the teachers to ran the schools and establish the rules for teaching rather than the pupils.
Isn't that the interest it's trying to protect?

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't read that from the record.
I believe that -- I believe in the record to what the school wants.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which do you think has the most right about control in the school, the pupils and their policies and teaching, the pupils or the authorities that are running the school?

turn.speaker: dan_l_johnston
turn.label: Mr. Dan L. Johnston
turn.text: The authorities that are running the schools under the authority given by them by the Constitution of the United States and within the provisions of that Constitution.
And the whole number of our case is that they of course that they've exceeded their powers under that.
Thank you.
